The fact is, I had employed an artist to decorate my exterior, but found him so deficient in that delicacy of touch as well as breadth of expression that forms so nice a point of art—in the department of white-washing—I was obliged to dismiss him; and, however awkwardly it may sound, sir, to white-wash myself.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Old friend, do you forget me?

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: Is it possible, Rawdon! Well, I'm vastly glad to see you,—so here I am you see, fixed at last; the great object of my life accomplished—my assembly rooms erected.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: So—I perceive.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: And with every arrangement to ensure their prosperity. Here is my supper room—there my card room—and yonder is my orchestra, capable of holding ten instruments besides the big drum—on that point I am strong. My band, especially in its brasses, is wholly unequalled; I believe that my brass, sir, is not to be matched—and as to our strings— you hear of musical chords that pull in the public; put my strings together, and they are as strong as a rope, sir.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Well, I am sorry I can't stay to hear them.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: Oh, but you must stay, if its only in justice to me. I'm not only manager and musical conductor, I'm also composer. Great occasions, you know, develope great powers: the opening of my rooms required to be marked by a new overture—so I walked about for half an hour, and whistled a grand one.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Whistled it?

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: Whistled it—to Stoggings, my leader, and he says it's a masterpiece. Its particular merit lies in its power of description, and on this head I don't think music has ever gone further. As, for instance, I call it “The Fall of Algiers,” and I commence with the sailing of the fleet—a pizzicato movement for the hoisting of the sails—and a solo on the trumpet to suggest the bosn's whistle. In part three, I describe the old admiral—an adagio movement to depict the moral qualities of a nautical commander—and I wind it all up with a modern imitation of a terrible bombardment—the whistling of bullets—the bawling of sailors—the neighing of horses—the crowiug of cocks—the downfall of the Turks—and the triumph of British principles.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: An expressive composition, certainly.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: Then allow me to put you down for a front seat.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Why, I must be off to-night—and therefore—

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: You'll prefer taking tickets—very good—four shillings each—or a family packet—six for a guinea.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Well, really, Prong, I should not object, but—

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: You think I ought to put you on my free list—well, as you're an old friend, I don't object—but I must tell you one thing—it's suspended for the season.

sp.speaker: Markland.
sp.p: No, thank you, I'll step in.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: Eh! who's coming? Ah! it's Markland.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Markland!

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: Yes; and by the bye, that reminds me he has a dinner-party to-day, and I have promised that the band shall play my overture to the company.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Well, I must delay no longer; my friend, I must tell you I am in haste to get to France;—is there a boat about here, going off to-night?

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.stage: They go off by the door, R. 2 E.
Markland and Susan come from the road, C.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Well, Susan, and how is your poor friend to-day?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Why, thank you, sir, I think she's a little stronger.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Then, in a week or so; we may hope to see her reestablished?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: No, sir,—I don't say that.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: But I say it—and with reason. Susan, I bring her news, that would almost raise her from the grave. I know, and cannot condemn your indignation at your late master. His treachery fully justified the abhorence you've expressed, but still he had excuses—it was not pride as you suppose, but want that caused his treachery. He loved your mistress deeply, but if he could only prove his truth to her at the hazard of a prison —must not some excuse be found for him in his dismay and his despair?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Why, certainly, sir.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p:
Be assured, Susan, that from the day he left her he has not known a moment's peace; his life has been but a protracted torture—hourly she has been before him, in all her desolation; and she not only—but the seared look of her poor deserted father. His one prayer has been to atone to her, and at length that prayer is granted—he had told his story to his
cousin, a good and generous girl, and she had released him from his contract—but still his uncle was unyielding and resolved on its completion. For three months that girl entreated him, and entreated him in vain—but love like hers was not to be defeated, within this week she has prevailed—Lascelles is pardoned—and is free to maintain his vows to Marie. (Rawdon opens the R. door returning, and seeing them, pauses)

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And—and is he coming, sir?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: He is here; now at the Inn—where I had the greatest labour to detain him—whilst I went in search of you to prepare her for the meeting.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Why, I really don't know whether I'm asleep or awake?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Now, lose no time, but run to her immediately, and mind you are discreet—do not tell her all—say merely, he is returned, and begs to see her.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Be speedy, then, or perhaps this meeting which promises such good, may become but the parent of augmented suffering.
sp.stage: He goes out at back, C.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Mr. Lascelles come back! come back to my poor misses to make her his true and lawful wife! I must be dreaming—yet—no Mr Markland says so—and I know he wouldn't deceive me, ha! ha! oh! isn't this delightful! I'm so happy —I—I—should like to cry, only I haven't time—and yet here I stand idling, when I ought to run and tell her—never mind the rooms—if they don't open for a month—I've got to wash the floor—but my husband can do that—and then go home, and fry some sausages—but he can do that too.—Dear, dear—only let me see her once more happy—and I don't think I should be wretched, if I was to bury Mr. Prong.
sp.stage: She runs off, at the back, C.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: So, then, Lascelles is free—and has returned to requite his victim. Are there not two here he should requite? Why should I leave England, seeking beggary abroad to avoid punishment at home—when he, who was the cause of my imprudence—can save me from its consequence? What made me use his name, but his own breach of faith to me? And with a hundred pounds I could regain the bill—he is now as rich as ever, and must assist me, eh—is not that he approaching? Yes; he has broken away from Markland, and hurries here half mad with joy, to clasp the feet of his forsaken—well, be it so—let hers be the first meeting—mine shall be the second.
sp.stage: Susan returns from the road, C.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p:
She is not at home—I had forgot that—and also—
heaven keep me—I was so surprised and overjoyed, I totally forgot to tell Mr. Markland, the state of my poor misses' mind—I have kept it secret, hoping every day she'd mend— but now, Mr. Lascelles is come, I must tell him, and yet how can I tell him, what will he say, or do, when he discovers that— Lascelles is heard without, C.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Marie! Marie!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Gracious powers! he's at the door.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Marie—are you here?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Yes, sir, I suppose so.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: And does not know my voice?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Well, perhaps, sir,—she is not within—she may have left the house.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: And which way—tell me—that I may reach her side at once.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Which—which way, sir?

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Why, what's this? Markland's not deceived me— she is well.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, yes, sir—she is well.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Then, why do you hesitate?—why hold back from me some news? which I can see, but too plainly shadowed in your face—when you know all that's past—when you know too why I am here—is she alive?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, yes, sir, and as I said well, but do be composed, sir, do now—you—you heard she's been very ill—for six weeks we gave her over—and though it's true she's now about again, of course she's very weak.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And if so in her body—she must be in her mind.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Her mind?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Yes, sir, you know what a shock it was—the night you went away—she was so happy at her father's coming—and you appeared so kind—and—and—altogether it was so sudden —and so terrible, that—

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: You,—you do not mean to say, that—that her mind has given way?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: It has indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Almighty heaven!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: For a time, I thought it was only brought on by her fever, and I hoped, when her strength returned, her reason would come with it.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: No, no, you cannot—dare not—blast me with a thought so horrible!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Indeed, sir, it's the truth.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: It cannot be—a momentary weakness—a casual word or action has deceived you.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, sir, I wish it were so, but haven't I watched her a week? Why, sir, she believes, that the evening on which you left her is still passing—that your friends are all assembled —and that you, whom she saw enter a carriage at the gate— will speedily return to them.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Yesterday, when she went abroad, she passed the whole day by the roadside, looking for your approach—and as she came back disappointed, she rose this morning, believing that you'd come to-day.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Then it's plain if she beheld me—my presence would restore her.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Why, sure enough, it might, sir—I never thought of that.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: It must, Susan—where is she now?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Sitting by the road, sir, I'll run for her directly—wait here only a moment, and—Eh! as I live, she is here.
sp.stage: Marie enters, her bonnet in her hand—she advances without observing them.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Susan! Susan!—he is not come. And now, he will not return to-night, I am sure—I'm sorry—for our friends will look for him—and my father too, how sad he'll be—well—well never mind, he'll be sure to return to-morrow, so we must prepare —are the rooms ready—the music, and the lights. (looks round) Yes—yes, tout est beau! all is charming!—so now I'll go, and dress—come, Susan, come— (she turns and goes to L. door—Lascelles, advancing R.)

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Now, now, sir—speak to her.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Marie!
sp.stage: (Marie stops at the door, and turning, surveys him without a recognition)

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Do you not know me?—'tis Edward!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Edward! I beg your pardon, he is not returned— he left me an hour ago to fulfil some errand at Southampton; but he will be back soon—very soon, long before the evening's over.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Marie!—do you not know me yet? What! not me—your own—your dearest—your espoused!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Susan!

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Marie, though your mind may be estranged, is there no chord within your soul to vibrate to my voice—to thrill at the name of Edward?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p:
Edward!—you know him, sir? Ah! is he not
worthy of your esteem? so generous, so good—if I could say how much he loves me. How assured I am that to save me from one hour's pain, he would sacrifice his life!

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Misery!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: But a thousand pardons, you must be waiting for a dance, the music's come, and here are enough friends for a quadrille; will you take a partner? (crosses to C.) (Music.—Turning from him, she goes round the room, bowing to imaginary couples, and pointing them to their places, then curtseys, as to a partner, who has asked her to dance) With much pleasure. (then waving her hand as to the music, she adds) Begin. (she then advances in the first figure of the First Set, returns to her place, pousettes, and advancing again for the ladies' chain, she hears a noise, and stops suddenly) Pardon! ces son la—a carriage! 'tis he—Edward! She rushes out at back.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Lost, lost, for ever!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Mr. Lascelles—

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: And I have wrought this ruin! I, that professed to love, to honor, and protect her!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You'll now, I suppose, sir, go to Mr. Markland's?

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: To meet his friends at dinner?

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And when will you set out, sir?

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: To-morrow.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: To-morrow, why, bless my soul, I'm afraid he's going crazy too—Mr. Lascelles, do speak to me—do, sir.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Well, Susan, what alarms you?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: 'Twill be getting dark, and as you must cross the fields to Mr. Markland's, hadn't I better show you the way? Since you were here, some chalk pits have been dug, and the path runs very near them, so I'll put you in the road. Now, you must not be disheartened, sir, because she didn't know you at once; when she sees you frequently, and hears you speak, and speak so kindly,—her reason must return, it must, indeed, sir!

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Yes, when he that has bereaved it, is resting in his grave!
sp.stage: He goes out at back, Susan follows him.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p:
This is fortunate, he means to cross the fields, the place of all others for our meeting; there we should have privacy, and time to talk. Yes, Lascelles, little as you look for me to-night—our difference bids fair to be adjusted! He goes after him.
Scene II. —The Chalk Pits at dusk. The fields stretch away in the distance, through which runs the high road; the pits lie at the back, edged by a low bank, and crossed by a plank, running off, R. U. E.; a pathway runs up a bank, L. U. E. Music.—Marie discovered on the bank, looking off towards the road.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Non, non, il n'est pas arrivé; Susan, he will not come to-night, I'm sure not. Ah! is it not sad, when all our friends are here, when my father desires so much to see him, well—well, it can't be helped; he'll come to-morrow, yes—he's sure to come to-morrow, so we must go on; is all ready, the music, and the flowers, and Susan—Susan—
sp.stage: She goes up the pathway, L. U. E.
Music.—Susan enters L. 1. E., followed by Lascelles.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Here are the chalk pits, sir, you cross them by that plank, it's quite safe, sir—and when you are through the field, you'll see your old house hiding behind that clump of trees.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Thank you, Susan, thank you.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Good night, sir, we shall see you again to-morrow, then? keep up your spirits, sir—now, do, I'm sure my misses will recover—she's certain to do that; she needs but to see you frequently.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: To detect a mind and spirit, as broken as her own.
sp.stage: Rawdon appears on the bank, L. U. E.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: This is the spot.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Marie, Marie! is not this at least atonement—ever to be by your side, yet ever to be unknown to you—ever to implore your pardon, yet win from you no reply—to meet nothing but your sad smile and your trust—the deeper condemnation of your own unchanged affection.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Lascelles, good evening.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: A friend, who can say he is present to you when you're most alone.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Rawdon!

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Even he!

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: And why have we met again?

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Why owing perhaps, to a law in physics—that bodies of a like kind exercise attraction.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Be plainer, sir, if you'd be listened to; you know, that between us all is at an end.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Then briefly as you wish; your banker holds a bill of mine, which you are pleased to call a forgery.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: When it is simply this—your name appended to a scrap of paper, to obtain a sum which you were pledged to lend me.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: But a sum, as I told you, that I was not possessed of.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: At any rate, you led me into the error, and 'tis your duty to repair it, I can't return to town—I want money to take me elsewhere, you are now rich again, and can lend me a hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: And you beg this of me?

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Beg this! I demand it. You ask me to speak plainly—and why not, when I'm injured?

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Injured! villain! Who, but you tore me from the arms of Marie?—do you know that she is now a maniac?

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: And if so—

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Then, in that blow—know that you crushed two minds—so, if you rob men of their reason, beware how you provoke them.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: You refuse, then, to assist me?

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Assist you? There's not a reptile, venomous and loathsome, that could crawl across my path, I would not sooner stoop to succour.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Beware, Lascelles!—you know that men are not exposed to want, without the power to overcome it.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: So, then, you're now grown honest?—you would at last rob openly?

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Beware, I say again!—tempt not a man's despair!

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Ruffian! be you discreet—know that I am armed!

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: And I; so you see we're still even, in everything but need. Again, I ask you—

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Then take this for my answer: be found here by to-morrow, and the prison you have fled from shall not forego its due.
sp.stage: He goes off by the plank, R. U. E.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Indeed! then I strike now for my life. That plank will bear but one of us, so guard yourself.
sp.stage: Music to end of Scene.—Marie descends the bank, L., looking off.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Susan—Susan!—yonder a carriage stops, and I think he has got down!—see if he is coming!

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Help! help!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Ah, quel voix est cela?

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: My arm was the strongest—but a tree has broken his fall, and if he climbs up the bank—'tis useless to pause now; I must return.
sp.stage: (he draws a knife, and preparing to return, Marie descends from R. path, and intercepts him)

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Stay. What would you do?

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Marie!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Who is it you would kill?—my husband?

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: No, your betrayer!—your enemy, and mine!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No, no; you must not harm him, for he loves me.

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Ah! by heaven he has struggled to the plank, and in a moment will be on it!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No, no!—kill me first!

sp.speaker: Rawdon.
sp.p: Give way, I say! (struggling to disengage himself, he throws her round to his left) Yes, by heaven, he is mounting it! Off! or if not—why perish with him! (lifting his knife to strike her, a shot comes from R., he totters and falls) Lascelles enters from R. path.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Marie! my preserver! She surveys him with a gleam of recollection, utters a low scream, and falls into his arms—Susan descends the path, L.—Scene closes in. Scene III. —An Apartment at Markland's. Prong enters, L., with a roll of music, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: Mr. Markland at home?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: Then will you tell him, if you please, that the band has arrived?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: And, moreover, that on this occasion, Mr. Prong will conduct the overture.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Very good, sir.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p:
And if that doesn't slide off a few “family packets” I am no judge of music. The fact is, I have found out in regard to music, that the conducting's everything; for what would the public know of it, if the conductor didn't explain it to them? A conductor in an orchestra, like one on the roof of a house—is an instrument to catch the electric fluid and transmit it to its recipients; I've studied in a good school; I've seen all the modern bands in London and in Paris, and I know all their evolutions—you always begin in this way. (he flourishes his roll, a la Jullien) With three good broad-sword slashes for a grand crash, in order to rouse attention—and then a series of gentle flutterings, like a sea gull going to dive—to waft the wind away into luxurious repose—presently a sudden burst, to create a slight perplexity—a hurry skurry of the fiddles, to make them ask, what's coming now—followed by a boom of the trombones, and a shriek of the French horns, as though you were going to charge them with a whole jungle of wild elephants—and then
when you are well at work—booming, screaming, thundering, till the audience begin to stare like a lot of delighted bedlamites; you calm the storm, and soothe all down till you look as if you were sinking in a warm sea bath. (a loud knocking, L.) Ah! the company to dinner. I've a great mind to bring that knocker into my overture, it would do a bit of the bombarding capitally. Servant crosses from L. hurriedly. Told your master, John?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, sir; but I must go now to my mistress, for here's Mr. Lascelles at the door with a lady that's fainted.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: A lady that's fainted?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, sir; Mr. Lascelles has been attacked, sir; just escaped with his life, so he's brought the lady here, and— you'll excuse me, if you please, sir?

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: Lascelles been attacked?—how very unfortunate! this will keep back the dinner half an hour—perhaps, too, spoil my music. My band must be in the way: I'll call them in. Gentlemen, will you step here, if you please? Enter three Villagers, with a fiddle, drum, and trumpet, L. 1 E. Gentlemen, I'm sorry to say, that owing to a little discord abroad, our harmony is likely to be interfered with within. However, we'll take our places on the lawn, and ascertain the distance at which we ought to stand. Distance, you know, has much to do with music—some we like near, some far off—and I wish to see, from your peculiar style of playing, whether yours would be most enjoyed near, or very far off. So follow me to the lawn—and allow me to say—that as I'm your conductor, I allow of no stoppages. They go off, R. 1 E. Enter Markland and Lascelles, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Why, Lascelles, this story of your attack, and your rescue at the hands of Marie, sounds like a romance.—Let me trust, however, that the only fiction, is your belief—that her mind is diseased.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Have I not told you her delusion—that the evening on which I left her is still passing—that my friends are still assembling—and I, that she saw leave her in a carriage, am not returning to rejoin them.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: I see—'twas the scene on which her senses closed— and it has burnt into her brain—and oddly enough—to-night, that you bring her here—I have some friends to dinner, and a dance—and—Lascelles—a thought—what if we tested this delusion—what if we realized the scene—which she imagines to be passing.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Realized it.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Aye—place her in that room once more, where her reason left her—and there surround her with the same images, and forms—and voices—

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: And then—?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Do you not think that such a pressure on her senses, would recall them.—And fortunately, as this is still your old house—the attempt could be made to-night—the room is still the same—or here is Susan, who remembers how 'twas furnished—and will help us to re-arrange it.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: But still—

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Nay, nay—if the scheme holds out the slightest ground of hope—'tis our duty to attempt it—be the issue what it may.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: I feel it is—but pardon me if struggle as I may, the thought will come—

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: That after all her suffering—some joy is yet in store for her.

sp.speaker: Prong.
sp.p: There—I've placed the band in a capital position— on the bank of the pond—so if they happen to slip in, their notes will be more liquid—and I think this is a good distance, two hundred yards—so here I shall try the effect of my production. I hope they'll play it with expression—particularly the bit about the admiral—the ten bars that describe the moral qualities of a good commander—by the bye—I was thinking, whether I couldn't improve that, by making the Admiral a Renegade—and then I could have some music to describe a man going into a foreign country—and changing his religion— well—they can see me here—so I'll give them the signal—now, gentlemen—begin. (he stands looking off, R., and flourishes; a bray of discords follow from the band) Hallo! what's that?—stop, stop! (their noise goes on increasing; he alternately flourishes and stops his ears, and at last rushes off to silence them) Scene IV. —The Parlours of the Villa (as in Scene III., Act II., furnished and lit in the same manner) Susan runs in from the lawn, smartly dressed, (as in Act II.)

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p:
Gracious me! what a thought of Mr. Markland's, to try to recover missus, by making her believe that the scene she is always thinking of is actually going on; it's not at all a bad notion, and should it succeed, she'll never know what she has suffered, or remember it only as a dream—and sure enough we can try it, for here we are in our old house, and the rooms
just as they were—not a chair changed, that I can see—everything looks the same;—I wonder whether I look the same! (goes to a glass) Well, pretty much, though to be sure, a girl's face is not so good for that matter, as a bit of mahogany—mahogany we know, improves by hard rubs—in fact it gets polished; but I can't say adversity has done as much good for me. Markland comes from R. door.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Now, Susan is, all in order?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Yes, sir; perhaps this table stood a little more here, and our flower stand, I think, was opposite.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Prepare, then—for whilst lying in her stupor, my wife succeeded in transforming her; in a few moments she will be here; you know your lesson—but be cautious.
sp.stage: He goes out at back, through R.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Be cautious! that's easy advice to give, but not so easy to take, when a body is so flustered;—I'm sure I shall make some blunder—I shall try to do it so well—I shall be able to do nothing—I shouldn't at all wonder if I wasn't able to speak at all! Enter Marie, R., dressed as in last scene of Act II., and advances in a reverie. Ahem!—Madam!—Mrs. Lascelles!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Yes, Susan.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You are dressed in time, I see—and—and—how charmingly you look to-night! Well, I am sure I hope Mr. Lascelles will win many sailing matches, when he makes you a present of such a beautiful dress as that—and oh! what a lovely bracelet—is that another gift to-day, ma'am? Why, the stone glitters like a star! (aside) I declare the stone has struck her! And that lace looks very splendid, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: The lace?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And that has struck her too!—I'm almost choked—but never mind, it will be only for a moment—and— and—how do you like the room, ma'am? don't the lamps burn nicely?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: The room!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p:
I have placed the flowers where you told me, in the vase. (a loud knocking at back, R.) Ah! just in time, ma'am—here are your friends arriving! (Marie runs to the lawn, and looking off a moment returns to the foreground, and stands rivetted) Eh! bless my soul—I'm afraid it won't do either; she is as fixed as ever, ma'am—Mrs. Lascelles. (more knocking, R.)
Markland enters from the lawn, with two Ladies. Mr. Markland, ma'am!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Good evening, Mrs. Lascelles—well, is our friend back from Southampton?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Southampton?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: I hear he went there on business, but promised to be home before your friends assembled.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I am sure he will.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Whilst your rooms, I see, as usual, have every resource to make them welcome—even the music you have provided.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: The music!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: The band from the Isle of Wight, which has arrived so unfortunately to rival that of Mr. Prong,
sp.stage: (a band begins to play at the back)

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: My friend, tell me, what is this? my brain aches as if it were on fire.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Dear me, ma'am, does it?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: But where's Lascelles? his friends here, and no host to receive them. Eh! isn't that a carriage coming up the road? it is.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: A carriage!
sp.stage: (she runs to the door, and looks off)
The Company now enter in a group and bowing to Marie, she advances with them to the fore ground.

sp.speaker: Visitors.
sp.p: Good evening, Mrs. Lascelles.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I—I—beg your pardon, but my husband, he is not returned—through I hope, indeed, I know that—

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, he is here.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: Marie! Marie!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Edward!
sp.stage: Lascelles enters, dressed as in Act II.

sp.speaker: Lascel.
sp.p: My wife! my wife! (she shrieks and falls on his bosom) —restored to consciousness—to happiness once more! (a group is formed around. Tableau). Curtain.
